'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2013-04-04 09:23:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

This interface looks usable now, but...

I'm still uneasy about this locking out other greenthreads,
while this change was added only for external lock part.
Note eventlet.semaphore does support trylocks, by changing
the context manager use to a try: sem.acquire(blocking): finally: sem.release(). If you did that though, given that
we only need the external lock part here, you then might
want the no-wait param to distinguish between internal, external, both and none. Getting messy IMHO.
So while this no_wait might be useful, I'd have it
include the greenthread semaphores too for consistency.
The use cases are marginal though, and so we might hold
off on the no_wait implementation until a real use case
is encountered, that would require the semaphores to not block?

As I previously mentioned, you can use external locks directly using something like the following,
which seems more direct and cleaner.

  lock_dir = CONF.lock_path or "/blah"
  fileutils.ensure_tree(lock_dir)
  lock = lockutils.InterProcessLock(lock_dir+'qa-mutex')
  try:
      lock.trylock()
  except IOError as e:
      if e.errno in (errno.EACCES, errno.EAGAIN):
          LOG.warn("lock already held")'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-04-04 12:19:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Let me check and I'll update accordingly.
Thanks
Gary"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-04-19 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-04-19 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Add no_wait to synchronized

Enable the call to have a no_wait option with
lockutils synchronized. This will raise an exception
(ResourceUnavailable) if the resource is currently used.

The no_wait option only applies to external locks.

Change-Id: I9fb7f5f67a90edea572716b9b347b1bb71e9aa5f

'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-02-05 02:39:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Nice work on this, I'm wondering however if the duplication of the iscsi code etc is the right way to go?  What about interfacing to cinderclient and creating a "new" type of read only volume specifically for image store?

I've been experimenting with this a little bit and it's rather handy, it's something like this:
1. Create an image-store volume (special type volume that's R/O)

2. Store the glance image, and update glance to have a record of the image and it's location (specifically provider_location)

3. Copy can use the clone functionality which is especially great for back-ends with advanced cloning capability

So far I've been mostly focused on bootable volumes but I think this can be extended for regular ephemeral instances as well.  I haven't quite figured out what that would/should look like yet, but maybe we could collaborate on this a bit?'}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-02-05 03:26:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Thanks for you input, John Griffith.
I agree with you and happy to collaborate with you. But I have two comments:

1 (suggestions). As we know, this iSCSI driver is a common implmentation for general iSCSI backend accessing, it allow Glance export LUN as an image from any iSCSI target but not only for Cinder iSCSI volume. Of cause you can expose Cinder iscsi volume also, but there is no limition.
Also, this iSCSI driver can support multi-path accessing, but Cinder can not now, since current Cinder iscsi volume based LVM does not support selective replication or full replication between multiple cinder-volume nodes.
So, I also consider we can land this store driver down, it can be used to access traditional filer/storage and there is no any limitation/relation with Cinder (iSCSI volume).

2 (collaboration). I agree with you, we have a driver for swift as a object storage back-end in Glance, so make a block storage back-end is make
sense to me, yep that is Cinder. Actually, before I implement this common iSCSI store driver, I have an idea to do this, but I think this way is more common, direct and simple to make iSCSI LUN/volume as an image, also it will not couple Glance with Cinder in some driver special code logic.

John, Shell we land this iSCSI store driver down firstly, and then let me prepare Cinder store driver, put your process into it (interface with cinderclient and upload/download read only volume as an image)?'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2013-02-13 00:53:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

John:

While I definitely agree with you as far as a more 'correct' solution as far as OpenStack integration, I think there is still a legitimate use for this store directly beneath Glance. We should continue to track the integration of this backend into the rest of the services and ensure it isn't use improperly, but I think it is fine to compartmentalize it here.

I'm working on a more thorough review for you, Zhi Yan Liu."}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-02-13 02:24:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Nice work Zhi Yan Liu, and yes I'd very much like to maybe work together on taking this even further during the H release.

I agree with your points as well as those made by Brian that there's good use cases that this will address as it is.

I plan to try and load this up and run it a bit, but the code review from my perspective looks good."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2013-02-21 16:24:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Do not merge

Unfortunatley, we are now under a feature freeze for Grizzly. Let's retarget this at Havana-1"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-03-08 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-03-08 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-03-08 08:58:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Restored'}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-03-21 02:22:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
Adding iSCSI backend store driver

Allow Glance expose any iSCSI backend volume (LUN) as an image
(such as Cinder volume). Client can retrieve it through single or
multiple path. And according to this, nova-compute can use the iSCSI
(through single or multiple iSCSI path) plus dm-snapshot method to
implement base image and its COW mechanism, this will decrease base
image creating time and effective improve provisioning performance.

Implement bp:iscsi-backend-store

Change-Id: I7e0c914d96a2fb385f091b7a5cf9b580256113c8
Signed-off-by: Zhi Yan Liu <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>

commit_message:
Don't swallow PolicyNotAuthorized for resize/reboot actions

Removes 'except Exception' lines in the api which were preventing
PolicyNotAuthorized exceptions from bubbling up and returning 403 to the
caller.  This addresses policy exceptions in confirmResize,
revertResize, and reboot.

The try block calls into the compute api which sends a cast to perform
to bulk of the work, so there is little chance of an exception bubbling
up which is not already being caught.

Removes a unit test for a condition that should not exist.

Bug 1170453

Change-Id: I516a19894ab3d183057c774e84c4faa7053a6463

commit_message:
Drop cache after fsync

Drop the cache (fadvise) after calling fsync to avoid redundant work
in the kernel visiting pages that are dirty. By dropping cache after
fsync(), the pages will be clean so can be easily removed from the
cache.

Change-Id: I3013d2ac1e27bbe43e58a81638d04805f5e2ae6e
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Remove unused exception and variable from scheduler.

There are no cost functions, so there is no cache and no Exception to be
raised.

Change-Id: I4a67bd45e3f0c91e5507ed3794dc20b13292596b

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-10 05:20:50.000000000', 'message': "Add parsing to extra-specs key check

When using the filter scheduler which is now the default,
we can no longer pass in extra-specs like: {minIOPS:500, ....},
because the capabilities filter will reject this because there is
no host reporting minIOPS:500 capabilities.

We now need to scope the keys (ie qos:minIOPS:500....), but
that unfortunately requires a fix to the SolidFire driver.

This change add a check for the ':' in the key, and parses
on it if it's there.

Fixes bug: 1167141

Change-Id: Ie7fd7d231af78cb18a13f44a4379b44d3c3385df
"}, {'created': '2013-04-12 19:58:30.000000000', 'message': "Add parsing to extra-specs key check

When using the filter scheduler which is now the default,
we can no longer pass in extra-specs like: {minIOPS:500, ....},
because the capabilities filter will reject this because there is
no host reporting minIOPS:500 capabilities.

We now need to scope the keys (ie qos:minIOPS:500....), but
that unfortunately requires a fix to the SolidFire driver.

This change add a check for the ':' in the key, and parses
on it if it's there.

Fixes bug: 1167141

Change-Id: Ie7fd7d231af78cb18a13f44a4379b44d3c3385df
"}, {'created': '2013-04-12 20:01:50.000000000', 'message': "Add parsing to extra-specs key check

When using the filter scheduler which is now the default,
we can no longer pass in extra-specs like: {minIOPS:500, ....},
because the capabilities filter will reject this because there is
no host reporting minIOPS:500 capabilities.

We now need to scope the keys (ie qos:minIOPS:500....), but
that unfortunately requires a fix to the SolidFire driver.

This change add a check for the ':' in the key, and parses
on it if it's there.

Also fixes backend_name and uses VERSION var instead of
generating string in stats reporting.

Fixes bug: 1167141

"}, {'created': '2013-04-12 21:18:23.000000000', 'message': "Add parsing to extra-specs key check

on it if it's there.

commit_message:
Add parsing to extra-specs key check

When using the filter scheduler which is now the default,
we can no longer pass in extra-specs like: {minIOPS:500, ....},
because the capabilities filter will reject this because there is
no host reporting minIOPS:500 capabilities.

We now need to scope the keys (ie qos:minIOPS:500....), but
that unfortunately requires a fix to the SolidFire driver.

This change add a check for the ':' in the key, and parses
on it if it's there.

Also fixes backend_name and uses VERSION var instead of
generating string in stats reporting.

Fixes bug: 1167141

Change-Id: Ie7fd7d231af78cb18a13f44a4379b44d3c3385df

'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-04-11 21:00:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Is it the case that a GET of a slob-manifest that points to another slob-manifest simply returns the second slob-manifest's contents and not its referenced files?

I took a look at the object server, and that appears to be the case, but I haven't tried it yet.

I ask because this fix looks good for validation, but if you actually can have recursive slob manifests, then there should also be a fix for that too lest someone figure out how to make a loop."}, {'account_id': 995, 'date': '2013-04-11 21:12:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

ya- my first thought was that it would return the manifest as part of the body but it really can't.  the HEADs from the middleware need to have the generated etag for it to pass (because that head goes through proxy server code) and the etag verification that happens while walking through the file would need to have the actual manifest etag for the file itself. i could put a special check for it but then gholt would make me write a unit test for it... :) I don't know- i will add it if anybody wants me to."}, {'account_id': 995, 'date': '2013-04-12 21:36:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-12 22:19:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

commit_message:
set bdm['volume_id'] to None

The bdm got from sqlalchemy is an object not a dict,
but in the unitest bdm is dict,
so just set bdm['volume_id'] to None rather than delete it

Fix bug 1166160

Change-Id: I880c18526de4df31ad6749afdcb803c57874a41d

commit_message:
Add x-remove-versions-location for feature: disable versioning

We can set x-versions-location empty to remove this header in API, but
to keep consistent, we should allow x-remove-versions-location too. The
usage is post "x-remove-versions-locaion: x", just like ACL remove
headers.

Fixed: bug #1107592

Change-Id: I1271eec6401d4a0e8c1a7c2d63aeb8dfef00bf6d

[{'created': '2013-04-11 16:34:49.000000000', 'message': "Fix bug in os-availability-zone extension.

Fixes bug 1167956.
The call to get the list of availability zones (GET V2/os-availability-zone)
doesn't hide internal availability zone if all services in that zone are
disabled.

Change-Id: I2c49ad68c2ee5ddea0536dfa770f649fbb392b63
"}]
commit_message:
Fix bug in os-availability-zone extension.

Fixes bug 1167956.
The call to get the list of availability zones (GET V2/os-availability-zone)
doesn't hide internal availability zone if all services in that zone are
disabled.

Change-Id: I2c49ad68c2ee5ddea0536dfa770f649fbb392b63

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-10 13:41:03.000000000', 'message': 'Fix _error_out_instance exception handler

Since Eventlet clears exceptions between greenthread switching, we need
to save that exception so it can be re-raised.

The _error_out_instance event handler did not wrap the quotas call with
the save_and_reraise_exception, so the original exception was lost.

Fixes bug 1163552

Change-Id: I69d28917aae1d787351cd800f8996532e5485eb2
(cherry picked from commit 25afdbbda8d56c509a4b34e0d6feeaafb2e46e5b)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix _error_out_instance exception handler

Since Eventlet clears exceptions between greenthread switching, we need
to save that exception so it can be re-raised.

The _error_out_instance event handler did not wrap the quotas call with
the save_and_reraise_exception, so the original exception was lost.

Fixes bug 1163552

Change-Id: I69d28917aae1d787351cd800f8996532e5485eb2
(cherry picked from commit 25afdbbda8d56c509a4b34e0d6feeaafb2e46e5b)

commit_message:
nova coverage create lots empty folders

with nova coverage extenstion disabled as a default behavior,
we noticed that a lot of empty folders is created under /tmp
folder. And also with each time the nova service reboot, it
will create new directory with name like nova_coverage_*.
WIth time go by, there will be nubmer of the empty folders
accumulated.

Fixes: bug 1169005

Change-Id: I85975b79f4da012c6fb0c37310d3390d3c692be0

This should be reverted. I did some debugging and found it to be a read herring. The message is due to exist? not tied into the user role modification method.  As you can see from this log, it doesnt in fact edit anything. The comparator in the code is done via whole array comparison:

 80     remove = roles - Array(value)
 81     add    = Array(value) - roles

My debug log: 

["Member", "admin", "project_manager"]
["admin", "Member", "project_manager"]
add=[]
remove=[]

debug: Puppet::Type::Keystone_user_role::ProviderKeystone: Executing '/usr/bin/keystone --token 1j23923yuc908140213je0i02rhaosdh0u3rep --endpoint http://127.0.0.1:35357/v2.0/ user-list --tenant-id 188f8249c6844bbcba06a36dcd6d9c6b'

(2 inline comments)

This fix needs improvement before merge. See inline comments. Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 7248, 'date': '2013-04-16 20:57:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

Digging-in to find root cause.'}, {'account_id': 7248, 'date': '2013-04-16 23:31:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

I did some digging. This error happens on calls to keystone_user_role on a user that is not already assigned permission on that tenant . In the case of a new tenant this will be always! The issue is chicken and egg. the code searches for the users id expecting the user to already be a member of the specified tenant... The fix seems to be to remove the tenant id on the user id lookup.'}, {'account_id': 7248, 'date': '2013-04-17 00:03:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-17 00:03:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

commit_message:
Fix user id lookup

    * User id lookup was filtered on tenant
    * Filter removed so retrieval od user_id always succeeds

Change-Id: I513d45d8f2cbe3d9c4edcbfa0b613c15ba4318e4

commit_message:
Fixed unicode username user creation error

The code tries to construct a byte string object to test the
length of the string field (The explicit construction of the
string object is neccessary as sometime v can be other types,
for example int). This will cause error if the string field
(v) is a unicode object.

Fixes bug #1166701

Change-Id: I73cee4da5c9f91ce135e7f81d88c979871f61767

"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-01-23 19:20:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

This is looking pretty good. I see a couple of issues:

a) we need to be careful not to mix source_type, dest_type, and driver_type. These are three separate things:

 - source of the bits
 - location of the active bits
 - how it is attached to the disk

it seems you are using device_type to represent source_type. I think ephemeral isn't a good name it should probably be something like blank. Swap is essentially blank + formatting so we might want things like 'blank', 'swap', 'partitioned', 'ext4'? I'm also not exactly sure what the point of NoDevice is?

b) we need an extension for the api changes. The extension doesn't need to do anything but it needs to be there so the functionality can be disabled and queried by clients.

c) we need to do size checking based on flavor (covered in my email)"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-01-31 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE consider splitting this into smaller patches, I see no reason for it being one big patch."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-04-08 23:05:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I agree with lifeless, this is unreviewable in its current state, IMHO. I'd much prefer to see smaller changes, even if a little glue is needed to make the transitions."}, {'account_id': 5511, 'date': '2013-04-09 11:11:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Thanks for the comments - I mostly agree with you guys that this patch is too big - it served more as an exploratory exercise to figure out all the places in the code impacted by the underlying db change - quite a few of them as you can see.

I think there is no way to do this in a smaller series of patches without glue code because the underlying DB structure is directly exposed as a dictionary to the code, and I don't think there is any sense in introducing a more high level API than that since it really is just a list of fields.

I will introduce a dict-like class for bdms (the glue code) that will know how to calculate it's own properties and hide the database migration from pieces of code that don't care about until the whole series is done."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-04-17 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-04-17 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Abandoned

'}, {'created': '2013-03-22 17:50:35.000000000', 'message': 'Block Device Mapping refactoring - DB & API layer

This patch is the first part of refactoring of how nova internally
handles block device mappings for instance.

This patch introducese the following high level changes:

* Migrates the database and adds new columns to the BlockDeviceMapping
table
* Introduces the API extension to handle the new data format that can be
passed to Nova and still be able to handle the old data model, and API
* Introduces more solid block device validation in the API layer.
* Refactors tests to be aware of the new data structure
* Introduces some common routines for dealing with block device mappings

The substantial size of the patch is due to the fact that block devices
are used heavily throughout Nova and changing the data layout resulting
in the need to tweak a lot of differents parts of the codebase. Going
forward there will be more work put into unifying the programming
interface through which nova code will deal with block devices so that
future changes can be less invasive.

More details on the new data model and the future interfaces are layed
out in the following wiki page:

https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/BlockDeviceConfig

blueprint: improve-block-device-handling

Change-Id: I76989a6a819405539733c0f354764129eeaeb5fe

commit_message:
Block Device Mapping refactoring - DB & API layer

This patch is the first part of refactoring of how nova internally
handles block device mappings for instance.

This patch introducese the following high level changes:

* Migrates the database and adds new columns to the BlockDeviceMapping
table
* Introduces the API extension to handle the new data format that can be
passed to Nova and still be able to handle the old data model, and API
* Introduces more solid block device validation in the API layer.
* Refactors tests to be aware of the new data structure
* Introduces some common routines for dealing with block device mappings

The substantial size of the patch is due to the fact that block devices
are used heavily throughout Nova and changing the data layout resulting
in the need to tweak a lot of differents parts of the codebase. Going
forward there will be more work put into unifying the programming
interface through which nova code will deal with block devices so that
future changes can be less invasive.

More details on the new data model and the future interfaces are layed
out in the following wiki page:

https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/BlockDeviceConfig

blueprint: improve-block-device-handling

Change-Id: I76989a6a819405539733c0f354764129eeaeb5fe

commit_message:
Add capabilities reporting to ThinLVM driver

ThinLVM driver was missing the newly required capabilities reporting
and inheritance from the parent LVM driver doesn't work because the
capacity reporting methods between regular LVM and Thin LVM are not
compatible.

This patch add the basic requirements needed in the capabilities reporting
to make it usable by the filter scheduler.

Fixes bug: 1166572

Change-Id: I471dcc31d07516e71bcd2d3ae03e0405e0594697

commit_message:
Improve Fedora build host support: PATH.

Fedora (and potentially other) build hosts will not automatically
have /usr/local/bin in their $PATH. We now detect its absence and
add it back.

Based on a patch from Lucas Alvares Gomes

Change-Id: Icbf1db7c5515d9274b4cd18c52ad8dafdc835718

"}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-04-05 13:32:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Libvirt has some support for OpenVZ. I'm not sure if it is sufficient to support OpenVZ in the context of Nova, but it could be improved if need be. As such I think that making OpenVZ work via the Nova libvirt driver would be a better approach, than creating an entirely new virt driver to maintain in Nova."}, {'account_id': 971, 'date': '2013-04-05 14:23:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

There have been significant bugs with regards to libvirt and openvz which is what prompted me to build this driver.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-04-05 14:26:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Wouldn't it be easier to fix those bugs than write a whole new driver?

I agree with Dan, I'd like to see compelling evidence for why it's better to do this than fix/use libvirt's integrated support. This adds a lot of code and debt to openstack, so care should be taken before we decide to go this route, IMHO."}, {'account_id': 971, 'date': '2013-04-05 14:44:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

As of the original writing of this driver libvirt's support of openvz only extended to containers with network devices and volumes were not supported.  Additionally there exists an issue within libvirt where the name of an instance has to be the same as the container's number which is an int.  So setting the instances name to the name given to it in nova is impossible.  At that time we submitted a patch to libvirt and it was ignored.  That is when we began the openvz driver for nova.  I'm a little confused at this point as to why we are now having this discussion as this blueprint was submitted as a new virt driver and was accepted years ago.  The support for openvz hasn't changed in libvirt either."}, {'account_id': 971, 'date': '2013-04-05 14:50:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

The code was previously reviewed and accepted but was just held back because we had no way of testing it at the time.  I am working with parallels and some folks at hp to get a testing image setup for devstack-gate to be able to test the driver.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-04-05 15:17:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I accept that the libvirt openvz support may not currently be sufficient, but we have to consider the long term maintenance impact on OpenStack. Each new virt driver in Nova has a significant maintenance cost over the long term. So even if we have todo extra work in the short term to improve libvirt's openvz support, and then make Nova's libvirt driver deal with OpenVZ, it would likely be a very significant net win to OpenStack over the long term."}, {'account_id': 971, 'date': '2013-04-05 15:52:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I understand your point but what we're now talking about is displacing work.  We're moving code, which is now done, to technical debt for an entity that may or may not have any interest in making the aforementioned changes.  I suppose we need to discuss this further but I find it completely disheartening to have had a blueprint accepted and then 7k+ lines of code later have that complete body of work rejected and that feature's support put off until an external group can completely fix their broken support for openvz.  This driver adds significant functionality to nova that allows users to manage openvz containers with volumes and network support including network fairness which doesn't exist in libvirt.  I don't have the time or ability to get these features working in libvirt."}, {'account_id': 971, 'date': '2013-04-05 16:26:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Work In Progress

There needs to be some in depth discussions on implementation on this, most likely at the summit.  Marking as WIP for now.'}, {'account_id': 971, 'date': '2013-04-05 17:16:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-04-05 17:22:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

"}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-04-15 13:07:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: Do not merge

Right now it seems to me the best approach here is to support openvz via libvirt.  Improving openvz support there has an even broader impact than just support in Nova.

I'm happy to discuss further and potentially be convinced otherwise.  The review isn't the best place, though.  This should continue on the openstack-dev mailing list.

Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 971, 'date': '2013-04-16 22:19:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Abandoned

Implementation rejected.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-04 15:26:48.000000000', 'message': "Adds openvz support to nova.

Implements blueprint bp/openvz-driver

This is my first attempt at wrapping up openvz that makes sense and gives
a greater level of control of OpenVz containers from Nova.  The driver is
known to work on debian based distros with flat networking using multiple
network interfaces.  There is some code for supporting redhat based distros
but will need to have some templates made.

In testing I haven't found any race conditions however we will be deploying
an earlier version of this driver in a beta service at some point so the
feedback from its heavier usage may lead to more improvements.

working copy of openvz driver in nova trunk

Fix logging imports.

adding openvz compatible compute.filters file

Add support for SSH key injection to OpenVZ driver.

code fixes to make openvz driver compatible with nova trunk

nova no longer requires connection.py

remove migration remnants and bring the driver api in sync with ComputeDriver

the new convention is to call a driver a driver and not a connection, renaming connection.py to driver.py

adding openvz driver to the driver.py file for inclusion in known drivers

fixed logger names

renamed openvzconnection to openvzdriver

refactor openvzconnection out of driver code

factor out FLAGS for CONF

fix moved module synchronized

fixed bad synchronized syntax

bulk unit test fixes for openvz unittests

more bulk updates for unittests

more unittest fixes

additional unittest fixes

pep8 fixes

more pep8 fixes

last fixes for test_driver.py

more tests fixed

fixed all unittests and pep8 violations

adding more unittest coverage

Additional test coverage

removing missing VIFDriver

removed db access from driver.py

refactor db access from utils.py

finished factoring out db access from utils.py

fixed broken pip-requires

change the way the openvz driver is presented through nova

fix driver object returned

changed conductor instance from LocalAPI to API

refactor config to pull from oslo

fixed bad import syntax for openvz driver

added some error checking to read_instance_metadata

changed code to handle metadata as it is currently returned from the conductor service

refactor db code in tc.py

change metadata update method to fix broken syntax

moving metadata to a list of dicts

changed metadata to system_metadata

changed metadata to system_metadata with key value pairs

empty metadata seems to appear as a list yet the update type takes a dict so we force the type to be a dict if read metadata is empty

if metadata returned from conductor isn't usable form, raise a type error

use utils.metadata_to_dict to coerce the system_metadata

additional debugging log entries

more metadata fun

more metadata fun

new system_metadata implementation

finish refactor system_metadata

fixed incorrect variable name

refactor system metadata stuff

fixed bad dict iteration in format_system_metadata

change calls to instance_types to use a conductor instance to gather instance_type information from the database

changed old LoopingCall objects to new FixedIntervalLoopingCalls

fixed LoopingCall object missed in previous commit

moved admin context from function call to it's own object to be passed around inside spawn method

first pass at integrating cinder api into volumes

remove call to delete instance from db if it's not found on the host at startup.  this was a bad idea to begin with.

pep8 fixes

more pep8 fixes

fix issue where partially deleted instance is half recreated on init_host()

set instance to deleted if not found on the host

fix instance_update

clean up instance using conductor to prevent deleted instances from being revived by compute manager

removed bulk volume operations in init_host as they shouldn't be necessary anymore

remove bulk volume operations from init_host

adding new local store for volume connection information

reenable some bulk volume operations for init_host to allow reconnection of volumes

fix attach and detach to use instance ref instead of instance name

fix session_currently_connected to handle case where no iscsi sessions exist.

fix broken syntax for reading contents in ext_storage and refactor driver to remove variables named 'file'

catch case where ext_storage file is empty

check the length of contents before trying to load it through json

added a try/except block to handle empty contents

fix save method to allow us to change the ext_storage file for an instance

mount the file systems for containers that are running already so that a container reboot isn't necessary

fix incorrect key name

add utils.py to access the mount and umount commands

change the arguments passed in for mounting filesystems

fix missing split() for mount line execution

fix up uuid so that we can delete the mount points

don't raise on failure of blkid command

only remove openvz related system_metadata as nova wants to find other stuff there

add uuids to instance description to recall uuids quickly to satisfy driver contract

make plug_vifs exit early if the instance is already running

fix instantiation of openvz bulk volume operations

refactor init_host to allow the compute manager to restart the instances

fix reboot syntax

Don't fail on unmount of internal mount. If this was a delete of instance it will already be unmounted

patch up tests to reflect recent changes

fix cfg imports in tests

fix cfg imports in tests

fix get_fs_uuid tests

fix test_stop tests

fix bad openvz driver instantiation

fix removal of db access from utils.py

remove references to instance_metadata_db methods

remove references to instance_metadata_db methods

fixup instance update

fix some virtapi issues

first pass at attaching raw devices

add a _let_disk_settle method to allow the os time to resolve network attached block storage before we try to do things with it

fix the disk settling code to be in the proper place and resolve the broken code that resolves symbolic links

add rootwrap filters

fixed fdisk command and added a short sleep to give the partition table time to resolve

add retry on listing devices as they may not have settled after partitioning

fix conditonal to better identify pertinent lines

change device listing to use globbing and regular expressions

first pass at mknod

add mknod command to compute.filters

fix device name to be the passed in 'mountpoint' which is also called mount_device in the connection_info

code to clean up devices

implement the call to detach devices

remove failure when vzlist returns no instances in memory check

change conditional to check for Container(s) not found

changed conditonal to be based on the existence of stdout

fix new issues with vzlist returning exit code 1 when there are no containers on the system

fix bad privs on device create

fix code path for raw devices to not include instantiation of mount/umount file handles when not using bind mounts

change sleep time from fdisk

soften errors in utils.execute when exceptions aren't important and cleanup fs_uuid stuff in volume.py

changed iscsi.py to be a proper child of OVZVolume

more changes to better follow the object model when using OVZVolume

fixed new order for ovziscsi driver instantiation

refactor to use saved block device names in the container config

fix issue where api will allow a user to create a raw device over an existing one

fix file read where line contains quotes

fix for reboot and resume_state_on_host_boot

change reboot() to use the context passed to it from the compute manager

moved around some volume code to isolate formatted volumes

remove old references to bulk volume operations and removed all code dealing with formatted filesystems to better conform to the nova virt driver contracts

removed ovz_use_raw_devices flayg because it's not needed anymore

removed references to raise_on_error for volume operations as this was part of the kruft needed to support formatted volumes

removed extraneous aruguments from super call in iscsi volume adapter

remove pexpect from pip-requires as we no longer require it

update license info

fixed missing index in _get_vz_device_list

add method to clean out all device entries in the ctid.conf file when the last device is to be removed

worked in some code to handle removing the last ephemeral volume from a container as this is a special case for openvz

fixed special case code that handles removing the last attached device from a vz container

unittest fixes

more unittest fixes

more unittest fixes

more unittest fixes

unittest fixes and remove conductor access from _set_instance_size

more unittest fixes

coerce root_gb to an int before doing math on it as the value comes from the metadata as a string

debug logging

fixed bad formatting character

more debug logging

removed one bad debug logging

more debug logging

fixed issue where vcpus passed into _set_cpus is coerced into an int because comparissons were failing

added a forced coersion in _set_ioprio as memory_mb passed in *could* be a string

changed add/remove devices to only log warning because raising on error causes instances that are being destroyed to raise errors that aren't recoverable

removed more code related to bind mounting filesystems as that codepath isn't needed anymore

fix unittests after removal of _clean_orphaned_directories

pep8 fixes

more pep8 fixes and unittest fixes

removed empty testfile

final unittest fixes

Change-Id: I2a1c41c50adac0d04ee418c6b572f6041462a321

a greater level of control of OpenVz containers from Nova.  The driver is
known to work on debian based distros with flat networking using multiple
network interfaces.  There is some code for supporting redhat based distros
but will need to have some templates made.

In testing I haven't found any race conditions however we will be deploying
an earlier version of this driver in a beta service at some point so the
feedback from its heavier usage may lead to more improvements.

Change-Id: I2a1c41c50adac0d04ee418c6b572f6041462a321

commit_message:
Adds openvz support to nova.

Implements blueprint openvz-driver

This is my first attempt at wrapping up openvz that makes sense and gives
a greater level of control of OpenVz containers from Nova.  The driver is
known to work on debian based distros with flat networking using multiple
network interfaces.  There is some code for supporting redhat based distros
but will need to have some templates made.

Change-Id: I2a1c41c50adac0d04ee418c6b572f6041462a321

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-16 07:36:26.000000000', 'message': "NetApp: Fix failing NetApp tests

The tests were failing due to an upgrade in the testing framework
(possibly due to upgrade of nose package from 1.2.1 to 1.3.0).
The actual reason was a bug in the suds client. A simple
workaround is utilised here, which sets the logging level of a
suds file to INFO instead of DEBUG.

Some 'FutureWarning' warnings from the test output were also
fixed.

Change-Id: Ia67476c23bffa91264cf79f6a26944b450c4f4fc
"}, {'created': '2013-04-16 12:22:05.000000000', 'message': "NetApp: Fix failing NetApp tests

The tests were failing due to an upgrade in the testing framework
(possibly due to upgrade of nose package from 1.2.1 to 1.3.0).
The actual reason was a bug in the suds client. A simple
workaround is utilised here, which sets the logging level of a
suds file to INFO instead of DEBUG.

commit_message:
NetApp: Fix failing NetApp tests

The tests were failing due to an upgrade in the testing framework
(possibly due to upgrade of nose package from 1.2.1 to 1.3.0).
The actual reason was a bug in the suds client. A simple
workaround is utilised here, which sets the logging level of a
suds file to INFO instead of DEBUG.

Some 'FutureWarning' warnings from the test output were also
fixed.

Change-Id: Ia67476c23bffa91264cf79f6a26944b450c4f4fc

commit_message:
Use a SSH pool to manage SSH connection

Use a SSH pool to hold all SSH clients.It allows 4 SSH clients
at most to connect to the SSH server at the same time.
This patchset also enables every SSH client connect to the other
controller when they failed to connect to the current controller.
For example,failed to A,then to B,or,failed to B,then to A.

Fixes bug: 1162251
Change-Id: I86f7f684639034be97ddf2031e61ac6bf3a196ad

commit_message:
xenapi: Make _connect_volume exc handler eventlet safe

`forget_sr` blocks and so clears the exception state causing the
subsequent raise to try to raise `None`, which fails.

Fixes bug 1167515

Change-Id: I18562c7389b152a6490d352c5a8d36934288f47d

commit_message:
Allow all headers requested for CORS.

- We allow all headers requested in preflight request. The CORS
  specification does leave the door open for this, as mentioned in
  http://www.w3.org/TR/cors/#resource-preflight-requests
  Note: Since the list of headers can be unbounded
  simply returning headers can be enough.
- This is a followup to review:
  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/24415/.
- Fixes bug 1155034.

Change-Id: If7b8f2f3a581c5209892d1ccc9f06ddb8fac92dd

While it is good to test the az option, I don't see any real value in testing with and without an az for every single one of these tests that calls create_aggregate."}, {'account_id': 6760, 'date': '2013-04-09 04:58:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi David, thanks for your review.

You mean az value should be checked each time create_aggregate is called? I don't figure out what real value means."}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2013-04-11 19:32:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I was saying two things. First, 

test_aggregate_add_host_get_details and
test_aggregate_add_host_get_details_with_az

are identical except for the az value. If both of these tests are needed then this parameter should be abstracted and the code not duplicated. But I don't see the need to duplicate each test for the case of calling create_aggregate with and without the az. It seems to me that doing this for one of the tests in this file would be sufficient."}, {'account_id': 6760, 'date': '2013-04-12 00:55:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi David, thanks for reply.

I understand. Get/list/add_host tests including create_aggregate with az would be duplicated, so I remove them.

I leave a test creating an aggregate with az to check if the correct value is set.'}, {'account_id': 6760, 'date': '2013-04-12 00:59:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-12 01:43:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

commit_message:
Add aggregate json client and tests.

This adds aggregate json client and tests for following functions.
* Create an aggregate
* Delete an aggregate
* Get aggregate details
* Get aggregate list
* Add host to an aggregate
* Remove host from an aggregate

Change-Id: I2c18f1f40bd0dad0565d60946571df0eae321aaf

commit_message:
Implement get_volume_stats for GlusterFS driver

Implement get_volume_stats(), so that the GlusterFS driver
will work correctly with the scheduler.

Fixes bug: 1164038

Change-Id: Ib4db8bad897212227b39704e2e6cb5f07f2bb70e
(cherry picked from commit d59094f316f0c41aaa7be63ee4e25e2dea4fa0a9)

commit_message:
/etc/hosts generator implemented

* small refactoring of cluster_ops.py;
* /etc/hosts is now generated for each node with all cluster nodes in it.

Change-Id: Ic30f5897f39f6782cc6edf13beb64783ed12e427
Fixes: bug #1168102

commit_message:
Support turning Sphinx warnings into errors.

The build team would like to be able to turn this on for projects.
Also, we should make it configurable. And while we're making that
configurable, we should also make autoindexing configurable.

Change-Id: I763329372be91afe442e87c7f3c0934763b4afc0

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-12 22:07:14.000000000', 'message': 'require sections are specified in nova_config

This massive code commit actually implements something very simple.

previously, we allowed nova_config to omit a section and assumed that
section was default.

This commit updates the code to require section names for all settings.

This change is being made b/c:
- it better maps to the config on disk
- it is consistent with the other modules

Change-Id: Iae71a4c48ed0f9792566f16f0bf13e61569b46e5
'}]
commit_message:
require sections are specified in nova_config

This massive code commit actually implements something very simple.

previously, we allowed nova_config to omit a section and assumed that
section was default.

This commit updates the code to require section names for all settings.

This change is being made b/c:
- it better maps to the config on disk
- it is consistent with the other modules

Change-Id: Iae71a4c48ed0f9792566f16f0bf13e61569b46e5

[{'created': '2013-04-05 12:15:09.000000000', 'message': "Drop Swift requirement on keystone:python.

I believe this requirement was added to obtain support auth_token
middleware (keystone auth support). This is now provided via
keystoneclient.

Since this requirement no longer works we should drop it since
it is heavyweight to install keystone source code on all the
swift proxies.

Most packages automatically require keystoneclient as well so
we can probably ignore automatically adding this dep in here. I'm open
to doing that if we thing it worthwhile... but we'll first need to
make a keystone::client module to support it.

commit_message:
Drop Swift requirement on keystone:python.

I believe this requirement was added to obtain support auth_token
middleware (keystone auth support). This is now provided via
keystoneclient.

Since this requirement no longer works we should drop it since
it is heavyweight to install keystone source code on all the
swift proxies.

Most packages automatically require keystoneclient as well so
we can probably ignore automatically adding this dep in here. I'm open
to doing that if we thing it worthwhile... but we'll first need to
make a keystone::client module to support it.

Change-Id: I2a85ea964d2b9e1a93c3ec0ba8de31b188c140ea

commit_message:
Set config_file_path in storage::node.

This change makes it so that storage::node sets config_file_path
for each of the services correctly. Previously this would cause
swift config file fragments to get written to
/etc/swift/<service>/600?.conf instead of /etc/swift/<service>.conf.

Fixes config issues for me on Fedora when using swift::storage::node.

Change-Id: I8d0ce87a545af805e24c5594b437483f9b479c9d

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-06 01:54:26.000000000', 'message': "Refactored lists of nodes to contact for requests

Extensive refactor here to consolidate what nodes are contacted for
any request. This consolidation means reads will contact the same set
of nodes that writes would, giving a very good chance that
read-your-write behavior will succeed. This also means that writes
will not necessarily try all nodes in the cluster as it would
previously, which really wasn't desirable anyway. (If you really want
that, you can set request_node_count to a really big number, but
understand that also means reads will contact every node looking for
something that might not exist.)

* Added a request_node_count proxy-server conf value that allows
  control of how many nodes are contacted for a normal request.

In proxy.controllers.base.Controller:

* Got rid of error_increment since it was only used in one spot by
  another method and just served to confuse.

* Made error_occurred also log the device name.

* Made error_limit require an error message and also documented a bit
  better.

* Changed iter_nodes to just take a ring and a partition and yield
  all the nodes itself so it could control the number of nodes used
  in a given request. Also happens to consolidate where sort_nodes is
  called.

* Updated account_info and container_info to use all nodes from
  iter_nodes and to call error_occurred appropriately.

* Updated GETorHEAD_base to not track attempts on its own and just
  stop when iter_nodes tells it to stop. Also, it doesn't take the
  nodes to contact anymore; instead it takes the ring and gets the
  nodes from iter_nodes itself.

Elsewhere:

* Made changes to reflect the above.

Change-Id: I37f76c99286b6456311abf25167cd0485bfcafac
"}, {'created': '2013-04-08 20:04:54.000000000', 'message': "Refactored lists of nodes to contact for requests

commit_message:
Refactored lists of nodes to contact for requests

Extensive refactor here to consolidate what nodes are contacted for
any request. This consolidation means reads will contact the same set
of nodes that writes would, giving a very good chance that
read-your-write behavior will succeed. This also means that writes
will not necessarily try all nodes in the cluster as it would
previously, which really wasn't desirable anyway. (If you really want
that, you can set request_node_count to a really big number, but
understand that also means reads will contact every node looking for
something that might not exist.)

* Added a request_node_count proxy-server conf value that allows
  control of how many nodes are contacted for a normal request.

In proxy.controllers.base.Controller:

* Got rid of error_increment since it was only used in one spot by
  another method and just served to confuse.

* Made error_occurred also log the device name.

* Made error_limit require an error message and also documented a bit
  better.

* Changed iter_nodes to just take a ring and a partition and yield
  all the nodes itself so it could control the number of nodes used
  in a given request. Also happens to consolidate where sort_nodes is
  called.

* Updated account_info and container_info to use all nodes from
  iter_nodes and to call error_occurred appropriately.

* Updated GETorHEAD_base to not track attempts on its own and just
  stop when iter_nodes tells it to stop. Also, it doesn't take the
  nodes to contact anymore; instead it takes the ring and gets the
  nodes from iter_nodes itself.

Elsewhere:

* Ring now has a get_part method.

* Made changes to reflect all of the above.

Change-Id: I37f76c99286b6456311abf25167cd0485bfcafac

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-09 14:01:35.000000000', 'message': 'Incorrect logging setup - duplicating root handlers

Stop adding the log handlers from the root logger to the logger specified via
the default_log_levels configuration setting. If the handler should dispatch
a event then it will do it once for the specified logger and once for root
logger thus duplicating the event.

Change-Id: I1a7880322ff53cbdf8048e1d805511ca76929ee3
'}]
commit_message:
Incorrect logging setup - duplicating root handlers

Stop adding the log handlers from the root logger to the logger specified via
the default_log_levels configuration setting. If the handler should dispatch
a event then it will do it once for the specified logger and once for root
logger thus duplicating the event.

Change-Id: I1a7880322ff53cbdf8048e1d805511ca76929ee3

In 02f59a0768a56c084fa72ac9c1e47f1a819baadc we removed:

  setup_requires=['setuptools-git>=0.4'],

from setup.py file and it broke tarball generation in that some files
are now missing.

Fixes: bug #1169295
"}]
commit_message:
Re-add setuptools-git to setup.py

In 02f59a0768a56c084fa72ac9c1e47f1a819baadc we removed:

  setup_requires=['setuptools-git>=0.4'],

from setup.py file and it broke tarball generation in that some files
are now missing.

Change-Id: I53997b68a4a36cae63d191d63bc19ef459c228c4
Fixes: bug #1169295

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-12 05:57:05.000000000', 'message': 'fix probe tests to work in a VM using mount_check

If mount_check is true (ie an SAIO with "real "devices, not loopback),
then the servers will correctly return 507 when given a nonsense path.
The first element is treated as a drive path, and that path isn't
mounted. This patch adds 507 as a valid status response to the server
check.

Change-Id: I1d1bb0ab78fd9ea17323635da7e686182fbdbf13
'}]
commit_message:
fix probe tests to work in a VM using mount_check

If mount_check is true (ie an SAIO with "real "devices, not loopback),
then the servers will correctly return 507 when given a nonsense path.
The first element is treated as a drive path, and that path isn't
mounted. This patch adds 507 as a valid status response to the server
check.

Change-Id: I1d1bb0ab78fd9ea17323635da7e686182fbdbf13

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-10 00:21:04.000000000', 'message': 'tgt include stack.conf via targets.conf, not conf.d

putting stack.conf in conf.d results in tgtd not starting with:
Config::General The file "/var/lib/cinder/volumes/*"
does not exist within ConfigPath: /etc/tgt! at /usr/sbin/tgt-admin line 172

This patch puts stack.conf in /etc/tgt and includes it explicitly
in targets.conf

Change-Id: Ifb6412f6860ceb28b724644fb9b618638f552102
Fixes: bug #1072121
'}, {'created': '2013-04-10 00:39:21.000000000', 'message': 'tgt include stack.conf via targets.conf, not conf.d

putting stack.conf in conf.d results in tgtd not starting with:
Config::General The file "/var/lib/cinder/volumes/*"
does not exist within ConfigPath: /etc/tgt! at /usr/sbin/tgt-admin line 172

This patch puts stack.conf in /etc/tgt and includes it explicitly
in targets.conf

Change-Id: Ifb6412f6860ceb28b724644fb9b618638f552102
Fixes: bug #1072121
'}, {'created': '2013-04-14 19:50:59.000000000', 'message': 'link /etc/tgt/stack.d to cinder volumes directory

This creates /etc/tgt/stack.d as a symlink to the cinder volumes
directory and includes it in /etc/tgt/targets.conf in a similar way
to /etc/tgt/conf.d

targets.conf only gets appended to when the symlink is created.
Any old /etc/tgt/conf.d/stack.conf is deleted

Change-Id: Ifb6412f6860ceb28b724644fb9b618638f552102
Fixes: bug #1072121
'}]
commit_message:
link /etc/tgt/stack.d to cinder volumes directory

This creates /etc/tgt/stack.d as a symlink to the cinder volumes
directory and includes it in /etc/tgt/targets.conf in a similar way
to /etc/tgt/conf.d

targets.conf only gets appended to when the symlink is created.
Any old /etc/tgt/conf.d/stack.conf is deleted

Change-Id: Ifb6412f6860ceb28b724644fb9b618638f552102
Fixes: bug #1072121

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-12 08:35:23.000000000', 'message': 'Add logging configuration

The tempest log can help developers analyze tests but
there is no option in run_tests.sh to enable logging output now.
This adds a logging configuration file and options in run_test.sh
and enables developers to get the tempest log more easily.

Implements: blueprint add-logging-configuration
Change-Id: Iee68a34f5771f1bff88110d95538a5b43103ced9
'}]
commit_message:
Add logging configuration

The tempest log can help developers analyze tests but
there is no option in run_tests.sh to enable logging output now.
This adds a logging configuration file and options in run_test.sh
and enables developers to get the tempest log more easily.

Implements: blueprint add-logging-configuration
Change-Id: Iee68a34f5771f1bff88110d95538a5b43103ced9

  Add a gettextutils.install() helper function

to get a new gettextutils.install() function which allows the default

Note that gettextutils.install() must be called before any other nova

to get a new gettextutils.install() function which allows the default

modules are imported since some modules attempt to translate strings
at import time (e.g. the 'message' attributes on classes in
nova.exception). This is broken and inefficient, but fixing it involves
adding something like spinx's l_() function and would be very invaisve.

Also, note that calling gettextutils.install() in nova.cmd.__init__
means that no program which uses a different translation domain should

Change-Id: I86562b3a65d371673bb21f7179eecc7602bc0775

commit_message:
Add NOVA_LOCALEDIR env variable

Part of fixing bug #995287

Syncs these two commits from oslo-incubator:

  Support overriding oslo localedir too
  Add a gettextutils.install() helper function

to get a new gettextutils.install() function which allows the default
localedir to be overwritten via an environment variable.

Note that gettextutils.install() must be called before any other nova
modules are imported since some modules attempt to translate strings
at import time (e.g. the 'message' attributes on classes in
nova.exception). This is broken and inefficient, but fixing it involves
adding something like spinx's l_() function and would be very invaisve.

Also, note that calling gettextutils.install() in nova.cmd.__init__
means that no program which uses a different translation domain should
ever import any of the modules under nova.cmd.

Change-Id: I86562b3a65d371673bb21f7179eecc7602bc0775

commit_message:
Fix some of the pyflakes warnings.

A couple of them are too much work for now, but this at least gets
a bunch of things where we're shadowing other variables, or even
referring to variables that don't exist.

Change-Id: Iefb72903220a15971a065de87c8fddb9a9f55553

commit_message:
Add filter support for keypairs

EC2 DescribeKeys has support for filtering keys by name
and by fingerprint. Using euca-describe-keypairs with
compute returns all of the names or fingerprints of a
given filter result.

Add filter to filter out results. LP: #1160850

Change-Id: I2531d719b8c032a0ca7f6d949c69078c88e0d346
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
